docs.lead_paragraph: JENNA PAXTON is an educated consumer. Never, before last year, had she hesitated to toss a store-brand food into her shopping cart to shave her grocery bill. Like many Americans, she buys cheaper generic drugs instead of the brand names, too. But during a routine trip last year down aisle 16A of an H.E.B. supermarket in Austin, Tex., she hesitated at buying a product she had never thought of before: generic infant formula. The idea of saving $3 a can piqued her interest. Still, her first child, Aaron, had started out on Similac, the national brand known to generations of parents. And when her second son, Cameron, was born, she stayed loyal.

headline.main: Formula Fight: A Generic Vs. the Giants

docs.abstract: Article on generic brand baby forumlas, which are just now beginning to be stocked on supermarket and drugstore shelves across US; generic formula represents substantial savings to parents and potential cash cow to retailers; photo (M)
